video.title: ...spread operator and rest operator - Beau teaches JavaScript
video.description:
The spread operator (...) spreads out the elements of an array (or iterable object). The rest operator condenses elements. The spread and rest operators are great additions to ES6!

🔗 Code: http://codepen.io/beaucarnes/pen/EWabjW?editors=0012
🔗 More info: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Spread_operator

Beau Carnes on Twitter: https://twitter.com/carnesbeau

⭐JavaScript Playlists⭐
▶JavaScript Basics: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbk2qRZtWSzCIN38JC_NdhW5
▶Data Structures and Algorithms: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbkso-IbgiiP48n-O-JQA9PJ
▶Design Patterns: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbnZtkAI3BqcYxKnfWn_C704
▶ES6: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbljtmmeS0c-CEl2LdE-eR_F
▶Clean Code: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbkK24EaPurzMq0-kw5U9pJh

-
We're busy people who learn to code, then practice by building projects for nonprofits. Learn Full-stack JavaScript, build a portfolio, and get great references with our open source community.

Join our community at https://freecodecamp.com
Read great tech articles at https://medium.freecodecamp.com

replies.author: Raquel Betancourt
replies.text:
I read your question when I was beginning to understand this concept and I was wondering the same thing, now that I am a little deeper into it I remembered your question and I can give you an answer

You must understand that in javascript there are two types of data

1. Primitives that are saved by value (numbers, booleans, strings, null, undefined, symbul, bigInt)

2. Compounds that are saved by reference (objects, arrays, functions)

So suppose you have two variables

let a = 10;
let b = a; // b = 10

What happens here is that Javascript saves both answers in different memory spaces making a copy of this

For example, when you use a photocopier, and you make a copy of a page, you have two completely different sheets, so if you break or scratch one of them, the other will not be affected, so, in the same code we do the following:

a = 20;
b; // b = 10

we will have that "b" will continue to be "10" since it was the value that was assigned to it at the beginning, it doesnt matter if "a" was changed

Now let's talk about data types that are saved by reference

Let's say we have the following

let array1 = [a,b,c];
let array2 = array1 // array2 = [a,b,c]

This type of data does not work the same as primitive data, here Javascript is not saved by value, it is saved by reference, so suppose there is a memory space called A1B2C3, in that memory space Javascript is going to save the value assigned to array1 and therefore the copy is made by that name/reference, so what we are really doing is

let array1 = A1B2C3;
let array2 = array1; // array2 = A1B2C3

Being A1B2C3 = [a,b,c]

So let's say that I want an array2 with the same data as array1, but I want to make some modifications to array2, but I want array1 to continue the same, what we could think of doing is

let array1 = [a,b,c];
let array2 = array1;

array2.push(d);

What ->we would expect<- to happen is

array1; // [a,b,c]
array2; //[a,b,c,d]

but what ->really happens<- is

array1; //[a,b,c,d]
array2;//[a,b,c,d]

but why? if I am modifying array2, not array1?


This happens because you are not modifying the value of the array, we are modifying the value of the reference, and since they both point to the same reference then you are modifying both.

How to solve it? using the spread operator, since when making a copy of the array, we are not taking the same reference, but we are creating a new one, so what you should do is

let array1 = [a,b,c];
let array2 = [...array1];

array2.push(d);

Then

array1 // [a,b,c]
array2 // [a,b,c,d] 

Hope this helps!

topLevelComment.author: ouf cena
topLevelComment.text:
...Spread operator allows an array to get more elements.
arr1.concat(arr2) == [...arr1, ...arr2];  //you can add more elements unlike .concat() function

...Rest operator allows  a function to get more arguments.
var multiply = (multiplier, ...args) => args.map( (element) => multiplier * element );
console.log(multiply(2, 1, 2, 3));

() means function
=> means return

map() method creates a new array with the results of calling a function for every array element.

replies.author: ouf cena
replies.text:
...Spread operator allows an array to get more elements.
arr1.concat(arr2) == [...arr1, ...arr2];  //you can add more elements unlike .concat() function

...Rest operator allows  a function to get more arguments.
var multiply = (multiplier, ...args) => args.map( (element) => multiplier * element );
console.log(multiply(2, 1, 2, 3));

() means function
=> means return

map() method creates a new array with the results of calling a function for every array element.

topLevelComment.author: Phil Hilton
topLevelComment.text: @2:07 You said the 4th element in the array is ignored "when it spreads it out" so you still get 3 in addThreeNumbers function. Is that true? I suspect is is more that all 4 elements are passed to the function, but since only the first 3 are named a parameters it is ignored within the function. In other words, the spread operator does not ignore it, but the function does, which is after is spreads it out.
